div.p: yeah so a lot of you may have heard of
access to justice or a group that's been
meeting here for a while now I just
hopped on the crew a few months back but
I don't want to spend too much time
explaining that group but basically what
we are seeking to do is to hack the
re-entry and recidivism process here in
Chicago and basically the challenges
that are involved in it so after a lot
and a lot of preparation and work we
finally had our first event and I'm to
go into detail on that and the less
slide but basically sorry so coming to
this group I'd know it no idea what
reentry and recidivism was so I'll be
the first to admit that but yeah
basically re-entry is after you're
incarcerated coming back into society
the process of experience and then
recidivism is after you're out of the
system going back into the system and
there's a lot of challenges that we had
found and we're experiencing other
people are having in this process and so
our goal was to come together as a group
and figure out the best way to attack
some of these challenges so as you can
see these are some of the popular stats
around this around the challenges which
brings us to the event that we had about
a month ago so this is a two day event
that we had in anglewood exactly a month
go from today and the first night we had
a documentary screening of two people
that are experiencing reentry and it
follows them through the process and the
second day we had our colab so what we
did was we group together a lot of us
and we had an event like I said in
Inglewood and the turnout was much
better than we thought there throughout
the day we've had about 70 people come
through most of which were from
communities around that area and
organizations that are also in the
business of helping this process and a
couple of the takeaways that we had
first and foremost was actually being on
the ground so to speak and not
necessarily working in this building now
it was a great experience for us it was
a great experience to be with the people
that are actually experiencing the
challenges they were trying to fix it
allows us to get on a much deeper level
what's important to them and the actual
challenges that they're facing because
we found out ahead of time that a lot of
the challenges that we thought they had
were not and they had a lot of
challenges that we didn't think about in
the first place so it was a great
education for us and helped us focus
moving forward on to what we think based
on what they're saying is important
another couple takeaways that we had
many of the challenges that they were
experiencing were around employment in
education they spoke a lot to not having
access to a lot of the resources that
everyone thinks they have so moving
forward we're going to be really
focusing on these specific challenges
and working with these people that we've
built relationships with now and
potentially outsourcing some of our
meetings to the angle would accelerator
which is where we hosted this event and
one of the other major takeaways was a
mindset change that we at least myself
experienced before hearing these
people's stories again I'll be the first
to admit that I initially thought well
if somebody is incarcerated as skids of
actions that they did and it's their
choice but really the truth is that
these people are born into a system that
they don't have any resources they don't
have any people around them they don't
have anyone to look up to they don't
have there been basically born into the
system that you know they go back into
car serration and come out and go back
and again so it definitely opened up a
lot of our minds on what these people
are experiencing and being able to be
more empathetic towards what they're
facing and then the last takeaway we had
were how important it kind of reflects
what we have here how important
diversity is and not only diversity in
people's cultural backgrounds but
diversity and the experiences that we
have the diversity and our ideas our
challenges that we face because the
cliche is diversity makes you stronger
but that's the truth not only diversity
and you know culture but also ideas and
challenges that we're facing so with
that being said we have tons of ideas we
love new people coming to our group and
we love to explain what we've learned
and what we're going to be doing moving
forward I want to do a quick thanks to
all the sponsors we had tons of support
from Jack night from a lot of our
sponsors for this event and we look
forward to
continuing to be the change that
everyone wants to see and to continue
with the reason why everyone's here to
help people and make the world a better
place for lack of better words thank you
[Applause]
